text.p: Anglo-Dutch publishing group Reed-Elsevier said on Monday it had agreed to buy MDL Information Systems Inc. of the United States for $320 million.
Reed-Elsevier said it would make a public bid of about $32 per share for all outstanding shares in MDL.
The company said it would use part of its short-term dollar deposit accounts in the United States to finance the deal.
The bid is being made through its Elsevier Science unit.
MDL is active in information systems data bases and supporting services, and has clients in the life sciences and chemical industries sectors.
The California-based company posted net profits of $11 million on turnover of $62 million in the financial year to March 31, 1996.
Reed-Elsevier said MDL would offer substantial synergy profits or advantages to Elsevier Science's other activities.
Elsevier Science recently announced it would develop ScienceDirect, a central on-line database through which information from its 1,200 magazines can be retrieved.
Reed-Elsevier said it expected to start marketing this new service by the middle of 1997, beginning with the contents of 350 life sciences magazines.
The bid depends on the approval of the U.S. anti-trust authorities. MDL shares closed at $17.25 on Friday.
